page.title: 03SHEEP FARMING IN HALTON
page.content: Mr Clough has about 480 sheep.The ewes are a cross between a Blue Faced Leicester and Swaledales;they are caleed Mules.The rams are Suffolks. His main reason for keeping sheep is for meat.The yearly pattern of his work is:January:Sheep fed on sugar beet tops and turnips.February:Sheep vaccinated against sheep scab,black leg,and foot rot.March-April:The baby lambs are born.May:Ewes and lambs are wormed.June:Shearing begins.The wool is taken to Horncastle for the haulier to take it to the Central Wool Growers in Market Rasen.The first lambs are sold to the Skegness Meat Traders.This continues until December at the rate of 10 lambs a week,when they reachg the weight of 90 lbs.July: The flocks isdipped.Mr.Clough travels to Appleby Sheep Market to buy ewes.October:The rams mate with the ewe.
